extracted_ttps.description: WinDealer malware is distributed via automatic update mechanism of select legitimate applications, convincing users to install fake updates
WinDealer specifically looks for popular applications in Asia, such as QQ, WeChat, and WangWang, indicating application window discovery.
Threat actor using signals intelligence methods and law enforcement tools to perform offensive operations

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The attackers may have the capability to intercept all network traffic, allowing them to receive backdoor responses and potentially exfiltrate data.
The attackers use a unique user-agent 'BBB' to identify their malware, specifically the downloader utility and WinDealer samples.
Threat actor leveraging capabilities to infect targets located in China through man-on-the-side attacks
The attackers target automatic updaters, exploiting them to infect targets with malware, specifically by abusing auto-update mechanisms.
Threat actor using man-on-the-side attacks to infect targets without requiring interaction
WinDealer uses a homemade binary protocol and executes arbitrary commands
WinDealer reads, writes, and deletes files, lists directories, and obtains disk information
WinDealer is distributed via social engineering, convincing users to install fake updates
WinDealer communicates with IP addresses selected randomly inside a specific AS
The attackers may use phishing or other social engineering tactics to trick users into installing the infected executable.
WinDealer collects hardware details, network configuration, and keyboard layout

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: WinDealer uploads arbitrary files to the C2 server
WinDealer performs network discovery via ping scan
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: WinDealer Malware Detection via User Execution
rules.description: Detects WinDealer malware distributed via automatic update mechanism of select legitimate applications, convincing users to install fake updates
falsepositives: Legitimate updates of PPTV application
False positives may occur if the legitimate application is updated and the filename matches the malware

rules.title: Detection: Application Window Discovery
rules.description: WinDealer specifically looks for popular applications in Asia, such as QQ, WeChat, and WangWang, indicating application window discovery.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration of data over command and control channels by monitoring network traffic and process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate network traffic to AS4134
False positives may occur if AS4134 is used for legitimate purposes
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application via WinDealer Malware
rules.description: Detects WinDealer samples or suspicious archiving tool usage associated with man-on-the-side attacks targeting Chinese systems

detection.condition: (selection_hashes or (selection_tools and selection_flags)) and not filter_benign_parents

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts using archiving tools with similar parameters
Software deployment processes using removal flags

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Office Process Spawning Shell with Archiving Flags
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command shells with archiving tool commands or suspicious flags associated with WinDealer phishing payloads

detection.condition: selection_parent and selection_child and (selection_archiving or selection_flags) and not filter_whitelist

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros using archiving utilities
Administrative scripts initiated from document templates

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: WinDealer Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of WinDealer's homemade binary protocol and execution of arbitrary commands, leveraging AES-encrypted data and RSA-2048 encryption indicators.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of encryption tools or secure communication software
System administration tasks involving encrypted data or secure protocols

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: WinDealer File System Manipulation Detection
rules.description: Detects file system manipulation by WinDealer, which reads, writes, and deletes files, lists directories, and obtains disk information
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Scripted file system operations by authorized users

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Remote Services – WinDealer random AS4134 connections
rules.description: Detects WinDealer.exe establishing outbound network connections to external IP addresses (excluding private ranges), indicating possible lateral movement via remote services (AS4134).

detection.condition: selection_process and selection_network and not benign_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate applications that communicate with external servers (e.g., Windows Update, browsers) but use different process names.
Enterprise monitoring or backup agents that may run under custom executable names.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: WinDealer System Information Discovery via Command-line
rules.description: Detects WinDealer malware collecting hardware details, network configuration, and keyboard layout via system commands like systeminfo, ipconfig, wmic, and reg query.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts
Network monitoring tools
Asset inventory systems

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using certutil and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using PowerShell and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Creates a directory for a fake update, downloads a benign file, and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The directory will be created, the benign file will be downloaded, and executed

attacks.description: Installs a fake update package using dpkg
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will attempt to install the fake package, potentially prompting the user for administrative credentials.

attacks.description: Installs a fake update package using rpm
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will attempt to install the fake package, potentially prompting the user for administrative credentials.

attacks.command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y /tmp/fakeupdate.deb
attacks.description: Updates the package list and installs a fake update package using apt
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will update the package list and then attempt to install the fake package, potentially prompting the user for administrative credentials.

attacks.description: List running processes and find the QQ application window
attacks.expected_behavior: List running processes and find the QQ application window

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to get the running processes and find the WeChat application window
attacks.expected_behavior: List running processes and find the WeChat application window

attacks.description: List running processes and find the WangWang application window
attacks.expected_behavior: List running processes and find the WangWang application window

attacks.description: List all windows managed by the window manager
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of windows, including their IDs and titles, to the console.

attacks.description: Search for windows with the class 'firefox'
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the window IDs of Firefox windows to the console, demonstrating how an attacker might search for specific applications.

attacks.description: Activate the window with the title 'firefox'
attacks.expected_behavior: Brings the Firefox window to the foreground, potentially demonstrating an attacker's ability to interact with or focus on specific application windows.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil for potential exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the contents of test.txt into encoded.txt in the temporary directory, which could be a step in preparing data for exfiltration over a command and control channel.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress sensitive data for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: This command compresses a file named sensitive_data in the temporary directory into an archive named archive.zip, also in the temporary directory, preparing it for potential exfiltration. The use of -Force ensures the operation completes even if the archive already exists.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate data using command and control channel
attacks.expected_behavior: This command reads the contents of exfiltrate.txt, removes any blank lines, and redirects the output to exfiltrated_data.txt, simulating data exfiltration over a command and control channel without using the internet.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic command to exfiltrate data over a command and control channel using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on port 8080 and saves any incoming data to a file named exfiltrated_data.txt

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate command to exfiltrate data over a command and control channel using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the attacker's server with the contents of the file at /path/to/data

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced command to exfiltrate data over a command and control channel using tar and netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a tarball of the data at /path/to/data, saves it to a temporary file, and then sends the file to the attacker's server using netcat

attacks.description: Download a benign file from a public-facing application using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temporary directory

attacks.description: Execute the downloaded benign file using powershell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be executed, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application

attacks.description: Create a directory, download a benign file, and execute it using cmd and powershell
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory will be created, the benign file will be downloaded, and then executed, demonstrating a more complex exploitation scenario

attacks.description: Downloads a payload from a URL and executes it using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes a script, potentially leading to further exploitation

attacks.description: Downloads an exploit, makes it executable, and runs it
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a downloaded exploit, potentially exploiting a vulnerability

attacks.description: Creates a benign payload file and reads it, simulating payload execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and reads a file, demonstrating basic file operations

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a file from a URL using certutil, which could be a step in a Phishing attack to fetch malicious payloads.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Simulate the execution or opening of a downloaded file using PowerShell, mimicking a user's action after a Phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the specified file with its associated application.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a benign command > %TEMP%\benign_command.bat && start %TEMP%\benign_command.bat
attacks.description: Create and execute a benign batch file to simulate the execution of commands that might be part of a Phishing attack's payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file with a benign command and executes it, demonstrating command execution that could result from Phishing.

attacks.description: Creating a file to simulate a phishing-related activity
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phish.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the text 'Phishing Simulation'.

attacks.description: Setting up a simple network listener to capture potential phishing inputs
attacks.expected_behavior: A network listener will be started on port 8080, and any input received will be saved to a file named capture.txt in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Downloading a potentially phishing-related HTML file from a controlled source
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML file named phish.html will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a command using cmd.exe, writing to a temp file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate example using powershell.exe to execute a command, demonstrating scripting capabilities
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Intermediate example' to the console

attacks.description: Advanced example using powershell.exe to start a new process, executing a command that writes to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named advanced.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Advanced example'

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a directory and write a test string to a file within it using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named testdir in the /tmp directory and a file named test.txt within it with the content 'Test Directory'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to write a test string to a file in a system directory using bash, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /etc directory with the content 'Test String', but this command poses a high safety risk due to its potential to overwrite system files.

attacks.description: List the files in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the files in the temporary directory without requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Obtain disk information for the C: drive
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays disk information for the C: drive, requiring admin privileges

attacks.command: copy con test.txt & echo Hello World! & exit
attacks.description: Create a new file named test.txt with the content 'Hello World!'
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file named test.txt in the current directory with the specified content without requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Lists the files in the user's Documents directory, demonstrating the ability to read local system data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of files and directories in the specified path without modifying the system.

attacks.description: Creates a new file in the /tmp directory, demonstrating the ability to write data to the local system.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named testfile.txt will be created in the /tmp directory containing the specified text.

attacks.description: Displays disk usage statistics, demonstrating the ability to obtain information about the local system's storage.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current disk usage and available space for each mounted file system.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify potential remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of currently running services on the local machine.

attacks.description: Simulates a connection to a remote service (in this case, a local port) to test network connectivity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Tests whether a connection can be established to the specified port on the local machine, simulating a remote service connection.

attacks.description: Establishes a Telnet connection to a local port, simulating interaction with a remote service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a Telnet session to the specified local port, allowing for interaction as if with a remote service.

attacks.description: Basic example of using netcat to connect to a remote IP address on a specific port.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection to the specified IP address on port 8080.

attacks.description: Intermediate example showing how to listen on a specific port for incoming connections using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Listens on port 8080 for incoming connections.

attacks.description: Advanced example demonstrating data transfer from the local machine to a remote IP address using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Transfers random data from the local machine to the specified IP address on port 8080.

attacks.description: Gather network configuration details using ipconfig.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network configuration, including IP addresses, subnet masks, and default gateways.

attacks.description: Collect system information, including hardware details and OS version, using systeminfo.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information, including OS version, hardware details, and hotfixes applied.

attacks.description: Use wmic.exe to gather CPU information, demonstrating advanced system information discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays CPU information, including device ID, name, and number of cores.

attacks.description: Gathers basic system information including kernel version, hostname, and operating system name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information such as kernel version, hostname, and operating system name.

attacks.description: Provides a brief overview of the system's hardware configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists hardware components in a concise format.

attacks.description: Displays network interface configuration and IP addresses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows the configuration of network interfaces, including IP addresses and subnet masks.

attacks.description: Basic ping command to a specific IP address
attacks.expected_behavior: The command pings the specified IP address, indicating if the system is alive and responding on the network.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using a batch loop to ping a range of IP addresses
attacks.expected_behavior: This command iterates through IP addresses from 192.168.1.1 to 192.168.1.254, pinging each one. The output is suppressed, but the command can be modified to log results.

attacks.description: Advanced command using PowerShell to ping a range of IP addresses
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the intermediate command, this PowerShell command pings IP addresses in the range 192.168.1.1-254, demonstrating network discovery with more modern Windows scripting capabilities.

attacks.description: Basic ping command to discover if a system is active on the network.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a single ICMP echo request to the specified IP address and report if it receives a response.

attacks.command: for i in {1..100}; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.$i; done
attacks.description: Intermediate command using a loop to ping a range of IP addresses (192.168.1.1-192.168.1.100).
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will iterate through the specified range of IP addresses, pinging each one and reporting any responses.

attacks.command:
#!/bin/bash
for ip in $(cat ip_list.txt); do ping -c 1 $ip; done
attacks.description: Advanced command using a script to ping IP addresses listed in a file named ip_list.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will read IP addresses from the specified file, ping each address, and report any responses. This method allows for easy modification of the target IP addresses by editing the file.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using rundll32 to inject into a benign process
attacks.expected_behavior: The command injects a benign process into another, leveraging Windows' built-in capabilities without causing harm.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection simulating a command execution within a new process
attacks.expected_behavior: The command starts a new instance of notepad.exe and writes a benign string to a temporary file, simulating process injection without actual harm.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to start a new process with arguments
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses PowerShell to start notepad.exe with a benign argument, demonstrating process injection capabilities in a controlled manner.

attacks.description: Inject a new process into a running process using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: The new process will be injected into the running process without causing any damage to the system.

attacks.description: Inject a new process into a running process using a custom program
attacks.expected_behavior: The new process will be injected into the running process without causing any damage to the system.

attacks.description: Inject a new shell process into a running process using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: A new shell process will be injected into the running process, allowing the attacker to execute commands in the context of the injected process.

attacks.description: Encode a test file and archive it
attacks.expected_behavior: A tar archive named 'archived.tar' containing the encoded test file will be created in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a zip archive of collected data
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'archived.zip' containing the collected data will be created in the temp directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Convert]::ToBase64String([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF16LE.GetBytes('Collected System Info')) | Set-Content %TEMP%\encoded_info.txt -Encoding UTF8; Compress-Archive -Path %TEMP%\encoded_info.txt -DestinationPath %TEMP%\advanced_archived.zip -Force"
attacks.description: Collect system information, encode it, and archive
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'advanced_archived.zip' containing the encoded system information will be created in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic command to archive collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.tar.gz containing the data from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Intermediate command to archive collected data using zip
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.zip containing the data from /path/to/data and its subdirectories

attacks.description: Advanced command to archive collected data using 7z with compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a highly compressed archive named archive.7z containing the data from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Capture the screen using mspaint.exe and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Capture the screen, encode the image, and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen, encode the image, and save it to a file named screenshot.txt in the %TEMP% directory

attacks.description: Capture the screen after a 5-second delay and save it as an image
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen after a 5-second delay and save it as an image file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Record the screen for a specified duration and save it as a video
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen and save it as a video file named output.mp4 in the current working directory. The recording will continue until the command is manually stopped.

attacks.description: Capture a specific region of the screen and save it as an image
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture a specific region of the screen after a 5-second delay and save it as an image file named screenshot.png in the current working directory. The user will be prompted to select the region to capture.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo test" /f
attacks.description: Basic: Adds a new registry key to run a command on startup using the reg.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run keys, and the command is executed on startup

attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses PowerShell to add a new registry key to run a command on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run keys, and the command is executed on startup

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Advanced: Adds a new registry key to run a command on startup and writes the output to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run keys, the command is executed on startup, and the output is written to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the user's bashrc file to execute upon each login.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be executed every time the user logs in.

attacks.description: Enables and starts a malicious systemd service, assuming it has been previously created.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious service will be started immediately and enabled to start at boot time.

attacks.command: sudo crontab -e; echo '* * * * * malicious_command' >> /tmp/crontab.txt; sudo crontab /tmp/crontab.txt
attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a malicious command at every minute, demonstrating persistence through scheduling.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed every minute.
